title: Radiation-Induced Neurologic Injury
icd10: G95.89 (Other specified diseases of spinal cord)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of radiation-induced CNS injury in adults. Covers acute radiation injury (during or within days of treatment), early-delayed radiation injury (1-6 months post-radiation), and late-delayed radiation injury including radiation necrosis (months to years post-radiation), radiation myelopathy, cranial neuropathies (optic neuropathy, vestibulocochlear injury, lower cranial nerve palsies), radiation-induced cognitive decline, radiation-induced leukoencephalopathy, radiation-induced cerebrovascular disease (moyamoya, cavernomas, accelerated atherosclerosis), and radiation-induced secondary neoplasms. Includes differentiation of radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence/progression (a critical diagnostic challenge). Excludes acute radiation syndrome from nuclear/radiological emergencies, brachytherapy-specific complications, and pediatric radiation injury (separate templates).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline hematologic status; rule out myelosuppression from concurrent or recent chemotherapy; lymphopenia assessment for infection risk
Essential/Core Labs.target: WBC, ANC, platelets within normal limits; ALC >500

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function for contrast imaging; hepatic function for medication dosing (steroids, bevacizumab); electrolytes (SIADH risk with cerebral edema); glucose baseline before steroids
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal electrolytes, renal and hepatic function; anticipate glucose elevation with dexamethasone

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Steroid-induced hyperglycemia baseline; many radiation necrosis patients require prolonged dexamethasone
Essential/Core Labs.target: <180 mg/dL; start insulin if persistently elevated on steroids

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Radiation-induced hypothyroidism screening (especially craniopharyngeal radiation, whole brain RT); fatigue differential
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (0.4-4.0 mIU/L); hypothyroidism common after whole brain or nasopharyngeal RT

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulation status if considering biopsy or surgical intervention for diagnostic uncertainty; anticoagulation status in patients with radiation-induced cerebrovascular disease
Inflammatory markers to help differentiate infection from radiation-induced inflammation; baseline for treatment response monitoring
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal or mildly elevated; markedly elevated suggests infection rather than radiation necrosis

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Bevacizumab teratogenic; methotrexate teratogenic if intrathecal considered; corticosteroid effects on fetus

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Glycemic status before initiating prolonged dexamethasone; perioperative optimization if biopsy planned
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <7.0% ideal; higher values require aggressive insulin management during steroid therapy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Radiation-induced hyperprolactinemia if hypothalamic-pituitary axis irradiated; amenorrhea or galactorrhea evaluation
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated suggests hypothalamic-pituitary radiation injury

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Adrenal insufficiency screening if hypothalamic-pituitary axis irradiated or prolonged dexamethasone use
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: >10 mcg/dL (AM); low suggests secondary adrenal insufficiency from radiation or steroid suppression

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Paired with TSH for hypothyroidism confirmation from cranial radiation-induced pituitary injury
Growth hormone deficiency screening; most common anterior pituitary hormone lost after radiation (>18 Gy to pituitary)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Age-appropriate normal; low suggests radiation-induced GH deficiency

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hypogonadism screening after pituitary/hypothalamic radiation; fatigue and cognitive complaints differential
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Age/sex-appropriate normals; low suggests radiation-induced hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Cognitive decline differential; nutritional deficiency contributing to neurologic symptoms
Baseline before bevacizumab initiation; proteinuria monitoring

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If clinical presentation atypical for radiation injury timeline; consider paraneoplastic syndrome mimicking radiation neuropathy
If leptomeningeal recurrence suspected as differential for progressive neurologic decline post-radiation
Emerging biomarker for distinguishing tumor recurrence from radiation necrosis; complement to imaging
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative or stable (elevated suggests recurrence rather than radiation necrosis)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If radiation myelopathy with longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis pattern; rule out coexisting autoimmune myelitis
Elevated VEGF implicated in radiation necrosis pathophysiology; may support bevacizumab treatment decision; research use

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ICP from edema or mass effect in radiation necrosis
Elevated in leptomeningeal disease, radiation-induced BBB disruption, or infection
Lumbar Puncture.target: 15-45 mg/dL; mild elevation common after radiation

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low in infection or carcinomatous meningitis
Malignant cells from leptomeningeal tumor recurrence (vs. radiation injury)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; positive indicates tumor recurrence, not radiation necrosis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Infection evaluation in immunosuppressed post-radiation patient
Lymphoma recurrence differential if prior CNS lymphoma treated with radiation

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately upon acute presentation; first-line for acute neurologic deterioration in previously irradiated patient
Essential/First-line.target: Hypodense area in radiation field; hemorrhage; mass effect; hydrocephalus; calcification in irradiated region

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (gadolinium)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h of presentation; GOLD STANDARD for radiation injury evaluation; compare to prior imaging including pre-radiation and post-radiation baseline
Essential/First-line.target: Radiation necrosis: ring-enhancing lesion within radiation field, surrounding T2/FLAIR edema, often indistinguishable from tumor recurrence on conventional sequences; early-delayed: diffuse white matter T2 hyperintensity; leukoencephalopathy: confluent periventricular T2/FLAIR hyperintensity; cerebral atrophy
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Essential/First-line.item: MRI spine with and without contrast (relevant levels)
Essential/First-line.timing: If radiation myelopathy suspected; symptoms of progressive myelopathy in previously irradiated spinal segment
Essential/First-line.target: T2 hyperintensity within irradiated spinal cord segment; enhancement may be present in acute/subacute phase; cord atrophy in chronic phase; may see focal necrosis or syrinx

Essential/First-line.timing: If radiation-induced cerebrovascular disease suspected (stroke-like presentation); moyamoya pattern; carotid stenosis from cervical radiation
Essential/First-line.target: Stenosis or occlusion in irradiated vessels; moyamoya pattern (ICA stenosis with collateral network); cavernous malformation; accelerated atherosclerosis

Extended.timing: Critical for differentiating radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence; obtain with diagnostic MRI
Extended.target: Low rCBV (<1.0-1.5) in enhancing lesion favors radiation necrosis; high rCBV (>1.75) favors tumor recurrence; mixed pattern common

Extended.timing: Differentiates radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence; obtain with diagnostic MRI
Extended.target: Radiation necrosis: elevated lipid/lactate peak, reduced choline, reduced NAA, low Cho/NAA ratio; tumor recurrence: elevated choline, high Cho/NAA ratio (>2.0), elevated Cho/Cr

Extended.timing: Superior to FDG-PET for brain; differentiating radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence when MR perfusion and spectroscopy equivocal
Extended.target: Low amino acid uptake (FET TBR <1.6) favors radiation necrosis; high uptake (TBR >1.6) favors tumor recurrence; FET-PET has sensitivity ~90% and specificity ~85% for this distinction

Extended.timing: Alternative if amino acid PET not available; lower specificity than FET-PET for brain lesions
Extended.target: Hypometabolism in radiation necrosis; hypermetabolism in tumor recurrence; limited by normal cortical glucose uptake

Extended.timing: Often included in standard brain MRI; helps differentiate radiation necrosis from abscess or acute infarct
Extended.target: Radiation necrosis: facilitated diffusion (high ADC); tumor recurrence: may show restricted diffusion; abscess: restricted diffusion centrally

Extended.timing: If moyamoya syndrome, radiation-induced vasculopathy, or accelerated atherosclerosis suspected
Extended.target: Intracranial or extracranial stenosis in radiation field; collateral vessel formation; aneurysm (rare radiation-induced)

Extended.timing: If cranial nerve VIII injury suspected from radiation to posterior fossa, cerebellopontine angle, or nasopharynx
Extended.target: Sensorineural hearing loss (typically high-frequency); speech discrimination decline; compare to pre-radiation baseline

Extended.timing: If optic pathway radiation injury suspected; radiation optic neuropathy
Extended.target: Visual field deficits corresponding to irradiated optic pathway; progressive visual field loss

Rare/Specialized.timing: When MR perfusion/spectroscopy and PET equivocal for recurrence vs. radiation necrosis
Rare/Specialized.target: Decreased uptake favors radiation necrosis; increased uptake favors viable tumor

Rare/Specialized.timing: If moyamoya syndrome confirmed on non-invasive imaging; pre-surgical planning for revascularization
Rare/Specialized.target: Detailed vascular anatomy; stenosis severity; collateral circulation assessment; Suzuki staging for moyamoya

Rare/Specialized.timing: Definitive diagnosis when imaging cannot distinguish radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence; guides treatment decisions
Rare/Specialized.target: Histopathology: coagulative necrosis, fibrinoid vascular necrosis, hyalinized vessels, telangiectasias = radiation necrosis; viable tumor cells = recurrence; mixed pathology common
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy; inaccessible lesion location; poor performance status

Rare/Specialized.timing: Radiation myelopathy evaluation; objective assessment of spinal cord function
Rare/Specialized.target: Prolonged latencies or absent responses at irradiated spinal levels

Rare/Specialized.timing: If radiation-induced plexopathy or peripheral neuropathy suspected (brachial or lumbosacral plexus radiation)
Rare/Specialized.target: Myokymic discharges highly suggestive of radiation plexopathy (vs. tumor infiltration which shows fibrillations without myokymia); denervation pattern in radiation field

Rare/Specialized.timing: If radiation optic neuropathy suspected; objective retinal nerve fiber layer assessment
Rare/Specialized.target: Retinal nerve fiber layer thinning; optic disc pallor quantification

Rare/Specialized.timing: Baseline and serial assessment of radiation-induced cognitive decline; essential for monitoring and intervention planning
Rare/Specialized.target: Deficits in memory, processing speed, executive function, attention; compare to pre-radiation baseline; progressive decline suggests late-delayed radiation cognitive injury
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Requires patient cooperation and adequate language function

Acute/Emergent.indication: Vasogenic edema from radiation necrosis; symptomatic mass effect; mainstay of initial medical management; reduces peritumoral/perinecrotic edema

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (cerebral edema from radiation necrosis) 10 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; moderate symptoms: 4-8 mg/day; severe edema/herniation: 10 mg IV bolus then 4-8 mg q6h (up to 16-24 mg/day); taper as soon as clinically feasible over 2-4 weeks; GI prophylaxis with PPI while on steroids
dosing.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (cerebral edema from radiation necrosis) 10 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes (relative); psychosis history (relative); chronic steroid dependence is common in radiation necrosis (often requires bevacizumab to facilitate taper)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h (target <180 mg/dL); BP; mood/sleep; GI symptoms; signs of infection; steroid myopathy (proximal weakness may mimic disease progression)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute seizure termination; seizures common in patients with cortical radiation necrosis

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe respiratory depression without ventilator
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat, BP, sedation level; airway equipment at bedside

Acute/Emergent.indication: Anti-seizure medication loading for new seizures in irradiated brain; preferred due to no CYP enzyme induction (does not interfere with chemotherapy agents or steroids)

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load, then 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; renal dosing if GFR <50

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: None absolute; reduce dose if CrCl <50

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute elevated ICP from radiation necrosis with significant mass effect; bridge to definitive intervention (steroids, bevacizumab, or surgery)

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus over 15-20 min; may repeat 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h; maintain serum osmolality <320 mOsm/kg

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Anuria; severe dehydration; active intracranial bleeding (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Serum osmolality q6h; serum sodium; I/O; renal function

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute elevated ICP; alternative to mannitol; may be preferred in hypotensive patients with radiation necrosis-related mass effect

dosing.instructions: 23.4% NaCl 30 mL via central line over 15 min OR 3% NaCl 250 mL IV over 30 min; target Na 145-155 mEq/L

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Sodium q4-6h; serum osmolality; I/O; central line required for 23.4%

Acute/Emergent.indication: GI bleed prevention while on dexamethasone; combined corticosteroid use increases ulcer risk

doseOptions.orderSentence: Pantoprazole (GI prophylaxis with steroids) 40 mg IV

dosing.instructions: Pantoprazole 40 mg IV/PO daily OR omeprazole 20 mg PO daily; continue throughout steroid course
dosing.orderSentence: Pantoprazole (GI prophylaxis with steroids) 40 mg IV

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizure maintenance therapy for patients with radiation necrosis-related seizures; preferred in neuro-oncology patients due to no CYP interactions

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; titrate by 500 mg/day q1-2 weeks to seizure control; max 3000 mg/day; renal dosing if GFR <50

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: None absolute; reduce dose if CrCl <50
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Behavioral changes (agitation, depression, irritability); somnolence; no drug interactions with chemotherapy

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Alternative or adjunct AED for seizures from cortical radiation necrosis; minimal drug interactions

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg BID; titrate by 50 mg/dose weekly; max 400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: PR interval >200 ms; 2nd/3rd degree AV block; severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG at baseline and with dose changes; PR interval monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Transition from IV to PO; taper as soon as clinically feasible; many radiation necrosis patients become steroid-dependent (requiring bevacizumab to facilitate taper)

dosing.instructions: Taper by 2 mg every 3-5 days (e.g., 16 to 12 to 8 to 6 to 4 to 2 to 1 to off); slower taper if symptoms recur; monitor for adrenal insufficiency if >3 weeks use; radiation necrosis patients often require very slow tapers

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Symptom recurrence (hold taper, reassess); cushingoid features (accelerate taper if possible)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Glucose; BP; mood; steroid myopathy; immunosuppression; osteoporosis; weight gain

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Glucose management while on dexamethasone; common and often prolonged in radiation necrosis patients on chronic steroids

dosing.instructions: Fingerstick glucose q6h; sliding scale insulin initially; basal-bolus if persistently >180 mg/dL; may need 2-3x baseline insulin on dexamethasone; anticipate glucose elevation 4-8h after steroid dose

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain from radiation plexopathy, radiation myelopathy, or cranial neuropathy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gabapentin (neuropathic pain / radiation plexopathy) 300 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q3-5 days; max 3600 mg/day divided TID; renal dosing if CrCl <60
dosing.orderSentence: Gabapentin (neuropathic pain / radiation plexopathy) 300 mg PO

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); respiratory depression (with opioids)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Alternative to gabapentin for neuropathic pain from radiation plexopathy or myelopathy; faster titration, more predictable pharmacokinetics

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; may increase to 150 mg BID after 1 week; max 600 mg/day; renal dosing if CrCl <60

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); CHF (Class III/IV)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; weight gain; peripheral edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain from radiation plexopathy; also addresses comorbid depression and anxiety common in radiation-injured patients

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1-2 weeks; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day for pain; take with food

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma; CrCl <30
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs; BP; suicidality (especially age <25); serotonin syndrome risk; hepatic function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Radiation-induced cognitive impairment; cholinesterase inhibitor may improve attention and memory in radiation-treated patients; evidence from RTOG 0614 and related studies

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; may increase to 10 mg daily after 4-6 weeks if tolerated; assess cognitive benefit at 3 months

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome; AV block (without pacemaker); active peptic ulcer; COPD (relative)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Heart rate; GI symptoms (nausea, diarrhea); weight loss; vivid dreams; syncope

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuroprotective agent for radiation-induced cognitive decline; RTOG 0614 showed delayed memory decline at 24 weeks (emerging evidence)

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5 mg weekly (5 mg daily, 5 mg BID, 10 mg AM/5 mg PM, 10 mg BID); max 20 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (CrCl <30); concurrent NMDA antagonists
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function; dizziness; confusion; reassess benefit at 6 months

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cancer-related fatigue and cognitive slowing from radiation injury; improves alertness, processing speed, and concentration

doseOptions.orderSentence: Methylphenidate (radiation-related fatigue and cognitive slowing) 5 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID (morning and noon); titrate by 5 mg/dose q3-7 days; max 40 mg/day; avoid evening dosing; reassess need monthly
dosing.orderSentence: Methylphenidate (radiation-related fatigue and cognitive slowing) 5 mg PO

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; tachyarrhythmia; severe anxiety; concurrent MAO inhibitors; glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Heart rate; BP; appetite; sleep quality; mood (agitation)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Steroid-induced osteoporosis prevention while on prolonged dexamethasone; radiation necrosis patients often on steroids for months

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 1000 mg Ca + 800 IU Vit D PO

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily while on steroids; check 25-OH vitamin D level and supplement if <30 ng/mL
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 1000 mg Ca + 800 IU Vit D PO

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Calcium level; vitamin D level; bone density if prolonged steroid use

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Depression and adjustment disorder common after radiation-induced neurologic injury; preferred SSRI due to minimal CYP interactions

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg q2-4 weeks; max 200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring; serotonin syndrome risk; hyponatremia (especially in elderly or those on dexamethasone)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Thyroid hormone replacement for radiation-induced hypothyroidism (common after whole brain, nasopharyngeal, or craniospinal RT)

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mcg daily (lower start in elderly or cardiac disease); titrate by 12.5-25 mcg q6-8 weeks; target TSH 0.5-2.5 mIU/L

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Untreated adrenal insufficiency (correct cortisol first); acute MI; thyrotoxicosis
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: TSH and free T4 q6-8 weeks during titration, then q6-12 months; cardiac symptoms

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Radiation necrosis refractory to steroids or steroid-dependent; anti-VEGF monoclonal antibody reduces vascular permeability and edema; Class II evidence supports efficacy; allows steroid taper in steroid-dependent patients

dosing.instructions: 7.5 mg/kg IV every 3 weeks for 4 cycles (some protocols use 5 mg/kg q2 weeks); infuse first dose over 90 min, then 60 min, then 30 min if tolerated; reassess with MRI after 2 cycles; may repeat course if recurrence

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; recent (28 days) surgery or wound healing complications; active hemorrhage; bowel perforation risk; pregnancy; severe proteinuria (>3.5 g/24h); prior arterial thromboembolic event
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP each visit; urinalysis for proteinuria q2-4 weeks; wound healing assessment; CBC; signs of GI perforation or thromboembolism; hold 28 days before and after surgery

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Symptomatic radiation necrosis refractory to medical management (steroids and bevacizumab); diagnostic uncertainty despite advanced imaging; progressive mass effect causing neurologic decline

doseOptions.orderSentence: Surgical resection (radiation necrosis) Per neurosurgical assessment Surgical

dosing.instructions: Resection of necrotic tissue with preservation of viable brain; confirm diagnosis histopathologically (coagulative necrosis, fibrinoid vascular changes, hyalinized vessels); post-op MRI within 48h
dosing.orderSentence: Surgical resection (radiation necrosis) Per neurosurgical assessment Surgical

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Poor functional status (KPS <50); eloquent cortex involvement precluding safe resection; diffuse necrosis not amenable to focal resection; medical comorbidities precluding surgery
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-op MRI within 48h; neurologic examinations; wound monitoring; continue steroids peri-operatively

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Radiation-induced fibrosis and late-delayed injury; anti-fibrotic and antioxidant combination; Class III evidence from small trials and clinical experience

doseOptions.orderSentence: Pentoxifylline + Vitamin E combination Pentoxifylline 400 mg + Vitamin E 1000 IU PO

dosing.instructions: Pentoxifylline 400 mg TID with meals (reduce to BID if GI intolerance) + Vitamin E (alpha-tocopherol) 1000 IU daily; continue for at least 6-12 months; benefits may take 3-6 months to manifest
dosing.orderSentence: Pentoxifylline + Vitamin E combination Pentoxifylline 400 mg + Vitamin E 1000 IU PO

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Pentoxifylline: recent cerebral or retinal hemorrhage; caffeine sensitivity; severe hepatic/renal impairment
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: GI tolerance (nausea, dyspepsia with pentoxifylline); bleeding risk (pentoxifylline enhances anticoagulants); INR if on warfarin

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Radiation necrosis or radiation myelopathy refractory to other treatments; promotes angiogenesis and tissue repair; Class III evidence; limited availability

dosing.instructions: 2.0-2.4 ATA for 90-120 min per session; typically 20-40 sessions; 5 sessions/week; benefits may be delayed weeks to months after completion

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Untreated pneumothorax; severe COPD with air trapping; claustrophobia; active seizure disorder (relative); concurrent bleomycin use
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Barotrauma assessment (ears, sinuses); oxygen toxicity symptoms; vision changes (myopic shift common, usually reversible); blood glucose (hypoglycemia risk)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Minimally invasive alternative to open craniotomy for radiation necrosis; stereotactic laser ablation of necrotic tissue; for deep or eloquent lesions not amenable to open resection

doseOptions.orderSentence: Laser interstitial thermal therapy (LITT) Per LITT protocol Surgical

dosing.instructions: MRI-guided stereotactic laser ablation; real-time thermal monitoring; can treat deep or surgically inaccessible lesions; typically single session; post-procedure MRI within 24-48h
dosing.orderSentence: Laser interstitial thermal therapy (LITT) Per LITT protocol Surgical

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Uncorrectable coagulopathy; lesion too large (>3 cm diameter typically); critical location precluding safe trajectory
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-procedure MRI; neurologic examination; may require ICU monitoring for 24h; edema may temporarily worsen (increase steroids peri-procedurally)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Spasticity from radiation myelopathy; first-line antispastic agent

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; titrate by 5 mg/dose q3d; max 80 mg/day; taper slowly to discontinue (withdrawal seizures risk)

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (accumulation risk); concurrent CNS depressants (additive sedation)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Sedation; weakness (may worsen functional mobility); hepatic function; abrupt withdrawal can cause seizures and hallucinations

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative antispastic for radiation myelopathy-related spasticity; alpha-2 agonist

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg qHS; titrate by 2 mg q3-7 days; max 36 mg/day divided TID; take consistently with or without food

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Concurrent CYP1A2 inhibitors (fluvoxamine, ciprofloxacin); hepatic impairment
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 1, 3, 6 months, then periodically; sedation; hypotension; dry mouth

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.indication: Radiation-induced secondary adrenal insufficiency from hypothalamic-pituitary axis damage; physiologic replacement (not anti-inflammatory dosing)

dosing.instructions: 15-25 mg/day in divided doses (e.g., 15 mg AM + 5 mg PM or 10 mg AM + 5 mg noon + 5 mg PM); stress dose: double or triple during illness or procedures; medical alert bracelet required

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.pretreatment: AM cortisol level; cosyntropin stimulation test if equivocal; rule out concurrent hypothyroidism (correct thyroid before starting cortisol to avoid adrenal crisis)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.contraindications: Active systemic fungal infection (at supraphysiologic doses)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.monitoring: Symptoms of adrenal insufficiency (fatigue, nausea, hypotension); electrolytes; glucose; stress dosing education

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.indication: Radiation-induced hypogonadotropic hypogonadism from pituitary/hypothalamic damage; fatigue, cognitive complaints, decreased libido, osteoporosis risk

dosing.instructions: Testosterone cypionate 200 mg IM q2 weeks OR topical testosterone gel 1% (50-100 mg daily); titrate to mid-normal range; gel preferred for stable levels

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.pretreatment: Baseline PSA; digital rectal exam; hematocrit; lipid panel; confirmed low testosterone on two AM samples; LH/FSH to distinguish primary vs. secondary
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.contraindications: Prostate cancer; breast cancer; polycythemia (Hct >54%); untreated OSA; desire for fertility (suppresses spermatogenesis)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.monitoring: Hematocrit q3-6 months (target <54%); PSA annually; lipid panel; testosterone trough level; liver function; mood and energy assessment

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.indication: Radiation-induced growth hormone deficiency (most common anterior pituitary deficit after radiation >18 Gy); improves body composition, fatigue, quality of life, and bone density

dosing.instructions: Start 0.2-0.3 mg SC daily; titrate by 0.1-0.2 mg q4-8 weeks based on IGF-1 levels; target IGF-1 mid-normal range for age; lower starting dose in elderly

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.pretreatment: GH stimulation test confirming deficiency; IGF-1 level; assess all other pituitary axes first; glucose tolerance; no active malignancy for 5+ years (generally)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.contraindications: Active malignancy or residual tumor (relative; endocrinology decision); diabetic retinopathy; uncontrolled diabetes
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Neuroprotec.monitoring: IGF-1 q4-8 weeks during titration, then q6 months; glucose; symptoms of fluid retention (edema, arthralgias, carpal tunnel); MRI surveillance of primary tumor per oncology

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuro-oncology consultation for differentiation of radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence, treatment planning, and coordination of bevacizumab therapy
Radiation oncology consultation for review of prior radiation fields, dose-volume analysis, and treatment-relatedness assessment
Neurosurgery consultation for surgical candidacy evaluation if refractory radiation necrosis with mass effect requiring resection or LITT
Neuroradiology review for advanced imaging interpretation (MR perfusion, MR spectroscopy, PET) to distinguish radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence
Multidisciplinary tumor board presentation for coordinated diagnostic and treatment planning in cases of diagnostic uncertainty between necrosis and recurrence
Endocrinology consultation for comprehensive pituitary function evaluation and hormone replacement after cranial radiation involving hypothalamic-pituitary axis
Physical therapy for gait training, strength maintenance, and fall prevention given radiation-induced neurologic deficits (hemiparesis, myelopathy, ataxia)
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, cognitive compensation strategies, and energy conservation techniques for radiation-related fatigue
Neuropsychology evaluation for baseline and serial cognitive assessment to monitor radiation-induced cognitive decline and guide cognitive rehabilitation
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation if lower cranial nerve radiation injury, and language assessment if dominant hemisphere radiation necrosis
Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain from radiation plexopathy or myelopathy not responding to first-line agents
Ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology consultation for radiation optic neuropathy evaluation, visual field monitoring, and management
Audiology referral for hearing evaluation and hearing aid fitting if radiation-induced sensorineural hearing loss from cranial nerve VIII injury
Psychiatry/psychology referral for depression, anxiety, and grief counseling given neurologic decline from radiation injury
Social work consultation for disability paperwork, caregiver support, community resources, and insurance authorization for bevacizumab or HBO therapy
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) consultation for comprehensive functional assessment and rehabilitation planning if significant neurologic disability from radiation myelopathy or necrosis

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for new or worsening headache, sudden weakness, vision changes, speech difficulty, or seizures (may indicate worsening radiation necrosis, edema progression, or tumor recurrence)
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to seizure risk, cognitive impairment, and visual field deficits from radiation injury
Do not stop dexamethasone abruptly as this may cause adrenal crisis after prolonged use; follow prescribed taper schedule exactly
Report any fever, signs of infection, or unusual bruising while on steroids or immunosuppressive therapy as these may indicate serious immunosuppression-related complications
Keep a symptom diary documenting headaches, seizures, weakness, cognitive changes, mood changes, and fatigue to track treatment response and disease progression
Wear medical alert identification indicating steroid dependence and seizure risk if applicable
Report new numbness, tingling, weakness in legs, or bladder/bowel dysfunction (may indicate radiation myelopathy progression requiring urgent evaluation)
Report visual changes including blurring, visual field loss, or double vision (may indicate radiation optic neuropathy or new cranial nerve injury requiring urgent ophthalmologic evaluation)
Discuss advance directive and goals of care, particularly in patients with progressive radiation necrosis or treatment-refractory disease

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Low-sodium diet while on dexamethasone to reduce fluid retention, peripheral edema, and hypertension from chronic steroid use
Blood sugar monitoring and diabetic diet while on steroids to prevent steroid-induced hyperglycemia and its complications
Regular low-impact exercise (walking, swimming, yoga) as tolerated to maintain strength, reduce steroid myopathy, improve mood, and combat radiation-related fatigue
Fall precautions at home including removal of trip hazards, use of handrails, non-slip mats, and night lights given neurologic deficits and seizure risk
Smoking cessation to optimize vascular health and reduce risk of accelerated radiation-induced cerebrovascular disease
Alcohol avoidance during treatment to prevent hepatotoxicity and avoid seizure threshold lowering in patients with cortical radiation necrosis
Cognitive exercises and engagement (reading, puzzles, structured activities) to maintain cognitive reserve and complement pharmacologic treatment of radiation-induced cognitive decline
Adequate hydration (2-3 L/day unless fluid restricted) to support renal function and prevent constipation, especially while on opioids or gabapentinoids for pain
CPAP compliance if obstructive sleep apnea present to prevent nocturnal hypoxia which may worsen radiation-induced neurologic injury
Weight-bearing exercise and calcium/vitamin D supplementation to prevent steroid-induced osteoporosis in patients requiring prolonged dexamethasone

differential.features: Most critical differential; enhancing lesion in radiation field may be recurrence or necrosis; occurs at similar timeframe; may present with worsening neurologic deficits identical to radiation necrosis
differential.tests: MR perfusion (high rCBV >1.75 favors tumor); MR spectroscopy (elevated choline, high Cho/NAA favors tumor); FET-PET (high uptake favors tumor); stereotactic biopsy for definitive diagnosis; mixed pathology (tumor + necrosis) common

differential.features: Transient increase in enhancement within 3-6 months of completing chemoradiation (especially with temozolomide); more common in MGMT-methylated tumors; may resolve spontaneously
differential.tests: Timing (typically 1-6 months post-RT); clinical stability favors pseudoprogression; serial MRI showing stabilization or improvement; MR perfusion may be equivocal; RANO criteria; biopsy if persistent

differential.features: Ring-enhancing lesion; may occur in immunosuppressed post-radiation patient; central restricted diffusion on DWI (unlike radiation necrosis)
differential.tests: DWI: central restricted diffusion (bright DWI, dark ADC) = abscess; radiation necrosis has facilitated diffusion; MR spectroscopy (amino acid peaks in abscess); blood cultures; fever, leukocytosis

differential.features: White matter lesions may mimic leukoencephalopathy; typically outside radiation field; younger patients; clinical relapses
differential.tests: Distribution outside radiation field; CSF oligoclonal bands; MRI dissemination in time and space (McDonald criteria); MOG/AQP4 antibodies

differential.features: White matter disease in immunosuppressed patient; asymmetric; no enhancement typically; may occur in cancer patients on immunosuppressive therapy
differential.tests: JC virus PCR in CSF; immunosuppression history; MRI showing progressive non-enhancing white matter lesions; no mass effect (unlike radiation necrosis)

differential.features: New lesion arising years to decades after radiation; different location or character from original tumor; meningioma is most common radiation-induced neoplasm
differential.tests: Long latency (typically >5-10 years for meningiomas, >3 years for gliomas); lesion characteristics different from original tumor; tissue biopsy for definitive diagnosis

differential.features: Acute onset; vascular territory distribution; radiation-induced vasculopathy may cause ischemic stroke in irradiated vascular territories
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion in vascular territory); MRA/CTA showing stenosis or occlusion; clinical history of sudden onset; vascular territory pattern (vs. radiation field pattern)

differential.features: Progressive cranial neuropathies, radiculopathy, cognitive decline after radiation for brain tumor; enhancing leptomeninges on MRI
differential.tests: CSF cytology (positive for malignant cells); leptomeningeal enhancement on MRI; elevated CSF protein; flow cytometry

differential.features: Gait disturbance, cognitive decline, urinary incontinence; may develop after radiation-induced adhesions or obstruction
differential.tests: Gait apraxia pattern; urinary symptoms early; CT/MRI showing ventriculomegaly out of proportion to sulcal atrophy; lumbar drainage trial; radiation history with posterior fossa involvement

differential.features: AEDs, steroids, chemotherapy may cause cognitive decline, fatigue, weakness mimicking radiation injury
differential.tests: Temporal relationship to medication changes; improvement with dose reduction or discontinuation; drug levels if applicable

evidence.recommendation: Bevacizumab effective for radiation necrosis; reduces edema and allows steroid taper

FET-PET superior to FDG-PET for distinguishing radiation necrosis from tumor recurrence
Memantine reduces cognitive decline during whole brain radiation therapy
Hippocampal avoidance during WBRT preserves memory
Pentoxifylline and vitamin E combination for late radiation-induced fibrosis

Radiation-induced hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction: long-term endocrine monitoring guidelines
LITT for radiation necrosis: safe and effective minimally invasive option
Radiation myelopathy: clinical features, pathophysiology, and management

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (motor, sensory, language, cognition, cranial nerves)
monitoring.frequency: q2-4h inpatient; each clinic visit outpatient
monitoring.action: STAT MRI if decline; increase dexamethasone; neurosurgery alert if herniation signs

monitoring.frequency: q2-3 months for first 2 years after radiation necrosis diagnosis; then q3-6 months
monitoring.action: Tumor board discussion if progression; advanced imaging (perfusion, spectroscopy, PET); consider biopsy if equivocal; adjust bevacizumab dosing

monitoring.frequency: q6h while on dexamethasone (q1h if insulin drip)
monitoring.action: Sliding scale to basal-bolus insulin; endocrine consult if refractory; consider dexamethasone dose reduction

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor; each clinic visit; critical if on bevacizumab
monitoring.action: Antihypertensives; hold bevacizumab if uncontrolled hypertension despite treatment

monitoring.frequency: Weekly if on bevacizumab; monthly if stable; q3 months long-term
monitoring.action: Hold bevacizumab if significant cytopenias; infection workup if febrile neutropenia

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; monthly during active treatment; q3-6 months long-term
monitoring.action: Adjust hepatically-cleared medications; evaluate for steroid hepatotoxicity
Adjust renally-cleared medications (levetiracetam, gabapentin, pregabalin); evaluate for contrast nephropathy
24-hour urine if >2+; hold bevacizumab if nephrotic range (>3.5 g/24h)

monitoring.item: Pituitary function panel (TSH, cortisol, LH/FSH, testosterone/estradiol, IGF-1, prolactin)
monitoring.frequency: q6-12 months after cranial radiation for at least 10 years (deficiencies can present years later)
monitoring.action: Endocrinology referral for hormone replacement; new deficits may emerge years post-radiation

monitoring.frequency: Continuous inpatient if recent seizure; patient diary outpatient
monitoring.action: AED dose adjustment; EEG if subclinical seizures suspected; verify medication compliance

monitoring.frequency: Baseline before treatment; then q6-12 months to track cognitive trajectory
monitoring.action: Cognitive rehabilitation referral; donepezil or memantine initiation/adjustment; occupational therapy

monitoring.frequency: q3-6 months if radiation field included optic pathway
monitoring.action: Ophthalmology referral; document progression rate; low vision rehabilitation if progressive

monitoring.frequency: q6-12 months if radiation field included cochlea or CN VIII
monitoring.action: Hearing aid evaluation; speech therapy for communication strategies
Psychiatry/psychology referral; SSRI initiation; supportive care

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if prolonged steroids anticipated; then annually
monitoring.action: Bisphosphonate therapy; calcium/vitamin D optimization; endocrinology referral

disposition.criteria: GCS <=12 or declining; signs of herniation (pupil asymmetry, posturing, Cushing triad); status epilepticus; acute hemorrhage into radiation necrosis; respiratory compromise requiring intubation; hemodynamic instability; post-surgical monitoring after craniotomy for radiation necrosis resection or LITT

New or worsening symptoms from suspected radiation necrosis requiring IV dexamethasone and close monitoring; seizures requiring AED optimization; post-procedural monitoring after stereotactic biopsy; diagnostic workup for radiation injury vs. tumor recurrence requiring inpatient imaging; steroid taper management with glucose monitoring
Known radiation necrosis with mild symptom worsening on stable steroid regimen; possible steroid dose adjustment with monitoring; MRI showing equivocal changes requiring multidisciplinary discussion

Neurologically stable for >=24h; seizure-free >=24h on oral AED if applicable; oral dexamethasone taper plan established with written instructions; glucose management plan in place; pain controlled on oral medications; follow-up appointments scheduled (neuro-oncology and radiation oncology within 1-2 weeks); safe ambulation and ADLs or adequate caregiver; patient and family education completed including return precautions

Need for advanced imaging (MR perfusion, FET-PET) not available locally; neurosurgical expertise for biopsy or resection not available; neuro-oncology consultation for bevacizumab therapy initiation; hyperbaric oxygen therapy not available locally; LITT capability not available

Significant neurologic deficits from radiation necrosis or myelopathy (hemiparesis, paraparesis, ataxia, cognitive impairment) requiring intensive rehabilitation; KPS 40-60 with rehabilitation potential

Progressive radiation necrosis refractory to all treatments (steroids, bevacizumab, surgery); progressive radiation myelopathy with no reversible component; severe radiation-induced cognitive decline precluding meaningful quality of life; patient and family goals aligned with comfort-focused care
